sys_hub_action_type_definition.description:
Create Virtual Machines from Image

Inputs:

  • Subscription ID - Uniquely Identify Microsoft Azure Subscription ID.
  • Resource GroupName - Name of the Resource Group.
  • VM Name - Name of the Virtual Machine.
  • Location - Resource Location.
  • Source Image ID - The Source User Image Virtual Hard Disk.
  • OS Disk
    • OsType - The Operating System of the osDiskImage.
    • Name - Disk Name.
    • CreateOption - Specifies How the Virtual Machine should be Created.
    • Caching - Specifies the Caching Requirements.
    • Disk SizeGB - Specifies the Size of an empty Data Disk in Gigabytes.
  • OS Profile
    • Computer Name - Specifies the host OS name of the Virtual Machine.
    • Admin Username - Specifies the Name of the Administrator Account.
    • Admin Password - Specifies the Password of the Administrator Account.
    • AllowExtension Operations - Specifies whether Extension operations should be allowed on the Virtual Machine.
    • Disk SizeGB - Specifies the Size of an empty Data Disk in Gigabytes.
  • Hardware Profile VmSize - Specifies the Hardware settings for the Virtual Machine,size of the VM
  • OS Storage AccountType - Specifies the Storage Account Type for the Managed Disk.
  • Network Interface - Specifies the list of Resource Ids for the Network Interfaces associated with the Virtual Machine.

Outputs:

  • Status - Will be set to "Success" if the request succeeds or "Error" if a failure in Virtual Machine occurs.
  • Error Message - Reason for error. Populated only when an error occurs. The status will be Error only in case of any failure in Virtual Machine.

Error Messages:

  • Subscription ID Invalid or Missing
  • ResourecGroup Name Already Exists
  • Invalid Connection
  • Unknown Error

To use this action, a corresponding Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine connection and credential must be created and associated with the Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine Connection & Credential alias. Learn More

Note: Requires a subscription for production use. Read More.

sys_hub_action_type_snapshot.description:
Create Virtual Machines from Image

Inputs:

  • Subscription ID - Uniquely Identify Microsoft Azure Subscription ID.
  • Resource GroupName - Name of the Resource Group.
  • VM Name - Name of the Virtual Machine.
  • Location - Resource Location.
  • Source Image ID - The Source User Image Virtual Hard Disk.
  • OS Disk
    • OsType - The Operating System of the osDiskImage.
    • Name - Disk Name.
    • CreateOption - Specifies How the Virtual Machine should be Created.
    • Caching - Specifies the Caching Requirements.
    • Disk SizeGB - Specifies the Size of an empty Data Disk in Gigabytes.
  • OS Profile
    • Computer Name - Specifies the host OS name of the Virtual Machine.
    • Admin Username - Specifies the Name of the Administrator Account.
    • Admin Password - Specifies the Password of the Administrator Account.
    • AllowExtension Operations - Specifies whether Extension operations should be allowed on the Virtual Machine.
    • Disk SizeGB - Specifies the Size of an empty Data Disk in Gigabytes.
  • Hardware Profile VmSize - Specifies the Hardware settings for the Virtual Machine,size of the VM
  • OS Storage AccountType - Specifies the Storage Account Type for the Managed Disk.
  • Network Interface - Specifies the list of Resource Ids for the Network Interfaces associated with the Virtual Machine.

Outputs:

  • Status - Will be set to "Success" if the request succeeds or "Error" if a failure in Virtual Machine occurs.
  • Error Message - Reason for error. Populated only when an error occurs. The status will be Error only in case of any failure in Virtual Machine.

Error Messages:

  • Subscription ID Invalid or Missing
  • ResourecGroup Name Already Exists
  • Invalid Connection
  • Unknown Error

To use this action, a corresponding Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine connection and credential must be created and associated with the Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine Connection & Credential alias. Learn More

Note: Requires a subscription for production use. Read More.
